findings.title: ELFM - Exceeds Fees Limit
findings.description: The contract owner has the authority to increase over the allowed limit of 25%. The owner may take advantage of it by calling the `setFee` function with a high percentage value.

findings.title: PVC - Price Volatility Concern
findings.description: The contract accumulates tokens from taxes to swap them for ETH, but if the `swapTokensAtAmount` variable is set too high, it may trigger a huge token swap, leading to significant price volatility due to the token's highly volatile price.

findings.title: PTRP - Potential Transfer Revert Propagation
findings.description: The contract does not tolerate potential reverts from underlying contracts during main transfer flow.

findings.title: RSML - Redundant SafeMath Library
findings.description: The usage of the SafeMath library adds complexity, overhead and increases unnecessarily the gas consumption since Solidity versions 0.8.0 and above have native functionality for arithmetic operations that revert on underflow and overflow.

findings.title: IDI - Immutable Declaration Improvement
findings.description: By declaring a variable as immutable, the Solidity compiler is able to make certain optimizations. This can reduce the amount of storage and computation required by the contract, and make it more gas-efficient.

findings.title: L02 - State Variables could be Declared Constant
findings.description: State variables can be declared as constant using the constant keyword. This means that the value of the state variable cannot be changed after it has been set. Additionally, the constant variables decrease gas consumption of the corresponding transaction.

findings.title: L04 - Conformance to Solidity Naming Conventions
findings.description: The code does not follow Solidity naming convention guidelines, affecting readability and maintainability.

findings.title: L05 - Unused State Variable
findings.description: An unused state variable is a state variable that is declared in the contract, but is never used in any of the contract's functions.

findings.title: L09 - Dead Code Elimination
findings.description: Dead code can occur due to conditional statements that are always false, functions that are never called, or unreachable code, making a contract more difficult to understand and maintain, increasing its size and deployment cost.

findings.title: L12 - Using Variables before Declaration
findings.description: The contract is using a variable before the declaration. This is usually happening either if it has not been declared yet or if the variable has been declared in a different scope.

findings.title: L13 - Divide before Multiply Operation
findings.description: It is important to be aware of the order of operations when performing arithmetic calculations. This is especially important when working with large numbers, as the order of operations can affect the final result of the calculation. Performing divisions before multiplications may cause loss of prediction.

findings.title: L14 - Uninitialized Variables in Local Scope
findings.description: Using an uninitialized local variable can lead to unpredictable behavior and potentially cause errors in the contract.

findings.title: L15 - Local Scope Variable Shadowing
findings.description: Local scope variable shadowing occurs when a local variable with the same name as a variable in an outer scope is declared within a function or code block.
